unnormalised: Someone asked me if it’s really necessary to address people by their corporate titles in India. Well, let me tell you a small story. I once interviewed a candidate, Ramesh, who kept referring to the HR Manager as “Sharmaji” throughout the entire interview, even after he introduced himself as “Mr. Sharma, HR Head”. Now, Sharmaji, err… Mr. Sharma, is a pretty chill guy, but I could see he wasn’t too impressed.
normalised: Someone asked me if it is really necessary to address people by their corporate titles in India. Well, let me tell you a small story. I once interviewed a candidate, Ramesh, who kept referring to the Human Resources Manager as “Sharmaji” throughout the entire interview, even after he introduced himself as “Mister Sharma, Human Resources Head”. Now, Sharmaji, err… Mister Sharma, is a pretty chill guy, but I could see he was not too impressed.

unnormalised: See, in India, corporate titles aren’t just fancy words; they represent experience, responsibility, and often years of hard work. Addressing someone as "Mr. [Surname]" or "Ms. [Surname]" when you know their official designation, like "VP Marketing" or "Chief Tech Officer," shows a level of respect. It signals that you acknowledge their position and the effort they’ve put in to reach it. It's especially crucial in formal settings like client meetings or presentations. Imagine calling the CFO, Mr. Patel, just "Patel Bhai" in front of potential investors!

It signals that you acknowledge their position and the effort they have put in to reach it. It is especially crucial in formal settings like client meetings or presentations. Imagine calling the Chief Financial Officer, Mister Patel, just "Patel Bhai" in front of potential investors!

unnormalised: Of course, workplace culture matters. In some startups, where everyone's on a first-name basis, it might be fine. But when in doubt, err on the side of formality. Calling someone "Director Verma" or "Dr. Iyengar, Head of R&D," until they tell you otherwise, is always a safe bet. Remember my friend Radhika? She got a job at a multinational corporation and constantly referred to the CEO by his first name. Her manager, Ms. Kapoor, had to pull her aside to explain the company's culture. So, yes, titles matter, especially if you want to make a good impression.
